title: Using Shape Expressions (ShEx) to Share RDF Data Models and to Guide Curation with Rigorous Validation
segmentation: Thank you so this is collaborative work.
My coauthors for this paper are Harold Solbrig, Gregory step, Jose Labra, Daniel Meachen, Eric Perdomo, and Andrew Agnes TER.
The link for these slides is here.
If you'd like to follow along and try any of the validation examples on your own machine.
A word about our collare
Operation we came to write this paper as two partially overlapping communities.
So we are members of the SCIEX Community Group and also active wiki data editors and some of us are participating in both of these groups.
Shakes is a formal modeling and validation language for RDF graphs.
Checks allows humans and machines to communicate unambiguously about data assets and checks.
Supports agile development of data models.
If you'd like to learn everything there is to know about checks, you can go to checks dot IO.
There are currently 5 implementations of Chex and JavaScript, Scala, Java, Python And Ruby.
Checks has a comprehensive test suite of more than 1000 validation tests.
At the time we wrote this paper.
99 negative syntax tests, 14 negative structure tests, and 408 schema conversion tests between the three serialisations.
There are two on line validators that you can access on the web.
The shakes two simple online validator written by Eric Perdomo in JavaScript and then RDF.
Shape written by Jose Labbra who's here with us today written in Scala.

Today we're going to talk about three of our use cases from the SCIEX Community Group fire from the medical domain gene Wiki from the biomedical domain, and then digital preservation from the domain of computing.
So fire stands for fast healthcare, interoperability, resources and a fire has a specification that defines more than 130 health care resources and how they are represented in RDF, XML, and Jason.
The fire documentation Production Framework itself natively calls the Shack Lex implementation.
And fires challenges to figure out how to exchange electronic medical records that have been generated in different software systems.
And so if you are interested in how this happens, there are great examples in the paper of the role that checks played in developing the RDF specification for fire.
Brief example of to give you a sense of what fire schema might be like.
Obviously we can't show real patient medical record data here, so this is kind of sample data.
In this schema you'll see in the purple pain there are two shapes, an observation shape and a patient shape.
The observation should have a status in the value set, preliminary or final, and subject matching a patient shape and a patient shape should have one or more names and an optional birthdate.
And then if you look on the green side of the screen there you'll see some sample data that would be in conformance with the schema I just described.
And this is just a screenshot of the.
Checks to online validator and there are links in the slides.
You can check it out and run this validation to see for yourself.
Use cases two and three are both coming from wiki data, entity data and there are a few notes here before we start talking about Wiki data, because a lot has happened since we wrote this paper.
So we have to catch up a little.
As many of you probably know, Wiki data does not have predefined data models.
Data models in wiki data are collaboratively created by the community and check schemas are already being used to share data models.
So that people have a concrete idea of what you're talking about, an check.
Schemas are also already being used to validate entity data in wiki data, which is very relevant for our ongoing work on data quality.

So the breaking news is that since last Tuesday the 28th of May, we now have a new namespace in wiki data Namespace E for storing schemas, and so previously we had all been storing our schemas on GitHub, which is excellent.

People can see them, but there weren't a lot of members of the wiki data community who were aware of these schemas or knew how to find them, so it's excellent for us working in the wiki data community to have these schemas actually.
On the wiki now and.
These schemas can be used directly to validate entity data in wiki data through the.
Version of the checks to online validator that has been implemented in Wikimedia Stool Forge, so I'll show you what this looks like in just a minute.
And part of the reason we're so excited about this is that now we can discuss and extend the schemas right on the wiki where people are already doing their work and paying attention.
The.
Wiki data namespace for schemas.
Also has support for multilingual link labels and descriptions and this we hope will allow people from even more diverse communities to collaboratively create these and extend these schemas.
And because it is part of the Wiki now, we have dedicated talk pages and revision history per schema and the talk pages being associated with the schema are really excellent because we can then.

Consolidate more of the conversation right there, where the schema is so somebody can more easily catch up on what discussions have already happened and then join in that conversation if they have additional ideas for how the schema needs to be extended or modified.
So this is a screenshot of what the E namespace looks like on Wiki data Now, so this is 1 schema.
And you can see everything is described here.
The properties that are expected.
You can indicate cardinalities.

You can indicate the shapes of the values that you're expecting and you'll see right now there's only one additional language code that has been let added for this schema, but you know it's only been up for a week.
It will be very exciting to see how more multilingual use comes into play here.
OK.
So our second use case is how checks is being used in the Gene Wiki project.
For those who are unfamiliar with Gene Wiki, this is a long running project.
It started in 2008.
Their original goal was to create and maintain infoboxes in English.
Wikipedia relating to human genes and then in 2012 after wiki data was introduced, they shifted from curating those infoboxes on English.

Wikipedia pages to actually curating the data on the corresponding wiki data items themselves and then rewriting the infobox templates to pull structured data directly from wiki data and then syndicate that on the English Wikipedia pages.
And then the gene Wiki team just kept on going.
They now have added more than 24,000 human genes, more than 20,000 mouse genes and more than 8000 disease content concepts from the disease Ontology and 2700 FDA approved drugs.
So if you remember yesterday in Peter's Keynote, the excellent insulin example with the rotating 3D model, we can thank the gene Wiki team.
For populating most of that data in wiki data.
And this is a screenshot of what the new version of info boxes that are driven by structured data from wiki data it looks like.
Alright, so.
I put a link in there so that you can try this validation example directly on wiki data yourself, But here's a screenshot just to go over it quickly here so.

On the top is the schema and then down below the blue part there the blue button says query map and you can enter the sparkle query to fetch the graph and then at the bottom of the screen shot there are the actual validation results that are produced so you can inspect those to see if something is nonconformance exactly which property was involved and what the error is.

The gene Wiki team has also developed the wiki data integrator, so this is a Python library that they use to write all of the bots that they run that actually populate their data on wiki data, and they've recently extended the wiki data integrator to incorporate paychecks and so now you can also validate entity data from wiki data from within the wiki data integrator, and you can also check.
For conformance in bulk across items so the gene wiki team is really doing a lot of leadership about integrating checks into their workflows for both data modeling and also validation.
And our third use case is from digital preservation, so this is actually the use case that I'm working in.

I work for Yale University Library and like many cultural heritage organizations, Yale University Library has a lot of legacy software in their collection, and this software could be anything from a CD ROM that comes in the back of a textbook to Digital Humanities website that is produced as part of a course to research data from the medical school.
That the library wishes to preserve and the software stored on, especially on CD ROMs and floppy disks, is at risk of deterioration.

And if people would like to use this legacy software which you can find in our catalogs, we can't always guarantee that we have the relevant computing environment available on campus with which they could interact with this software.
So the solution that Yale University Library is using is called emulation as a service.

Where we provide a preconfigured emulated computing environment in the browser so users can use that to interact with their legacy software item of choice without needing to know anything about emulation or how to configure a emulated environment.

But in order to do this, we need a lot of metadata and we have chosen to create this metadata in wiki data so that it will be linked open data and we can use it even more widely than just for emulation as a service.
So people working in digital preservation all over have a shared need for.
High quality metadata about common resources in the domain computing.

And we use checks to write data models for software file formats, emulators, everything in wiki data, and then we can use these schemas to gather feedback and come to more general agreement about the models.
As we're editing on wiki data, and then we also use checks to test entity data for conformance to these schemas.
Because of course, we're not the only people who are describing resources.
Domain of computing.
In Wiki data, many people are doing this and.
If we would like to be able to reuse other people's data, we need to make sure that we're using compatible data models.
And here is another screenshot of validation of a schema that describes the structure of file formats on wiki data.
And again you can.
Test this on your own.
Here it was just limited to 10 items, but you can remove the limit and test as many items as you would like for conformance.
So why shacks my answer for this question is there are implementations in multiple languages available under open source licenses?
You like to emphasize the concise human readable syntax, so this means that it's relatively easy to write schemas in the text editor of your choice.
And the comprehensive Test suite gives us confidence that the tools are behaving in the way that we would expect them to, and that the different implementations are isomorphic.
If you'd like to learn more about checks, you could check scolia.
Scolia is a wiki data based service that generates scholarly profiles and all of the scientific articles that have main subject of checks you can find in scholia under the topic aspect.
So this is just a screenshot of the very top of the scholia page.
You can follow the link to see the full data set.

If you'd like a quick start to get going with checks, I'd recommend the primer the primer was written by the SCIEX Community Group, and it's meant to be more accessible starting point than just reading all the specs.

If you'd like to get started with checks on Wiki data specifically, we have Wiki data, wiki project checks where we are coordinating all of the exciting activity around this knew namespace E, and you could also review the schemas that have already been contributed to wiki data.
When I checked yesterday, I think there's already 70 schemas and this was just announced last week, so I personally I'm really happy to see that so many people are already trying this out.
In sharing their schemas.
If you'd like to join the conversation about checks, this is a link to our Gitter channel.
You're more than welcome to participate.
And if Chex becomes of great interest to you, I'd also like to invite you to join our W. 3C Community Group, where you can talk with all of us about the future of shakes.
Thank you very much.
